content.text: You have been provided with a chain of fifteen paper clips with a sphere of modelling clay attached to one end of the chain
Measure and record the length \(L\) of one paper clip as shown in Fig. 1.1
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.2
The chain should be suspended from the nail
The wooden rod should be positioned so that the chain, when hanging vertically, just touches the rod with 6 paper clips below the rod
Record the number \(n\) of paper clips below the rod
n =
Move the sphere towards you through a distance of approximately \(10 \text{cm}\)
Release the sphere. The chain will oscillate and hit the rod during these oscillations
Determine the period \(T\) of the oscillations
Change \(n\) by moving the wooden rod vertically and repeat **(b)**(ii) and **(c)** until you have six sets of values of \(n\) and \(T\)
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\sqrt{n}\) to three significant figures in your table
\(\square\)
\(\square\)
Plot a graph of \(T\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\sqrt{n}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants
Using your answers in **(e)**(iii), determine the values of \(P\) and \(Q\)
Give appropriate units

where \(g\) is the acceleration of free fall

In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of a chain of paper clips
You have been provided with a metre rule with a hole close to each end as shown in Fig. 2.1
The distance between the centres of the holes is \(A\)
Measure and record \(A\)
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2
Adjust the position of the rule until it is balanced
The distance between the centre of the hole from which the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass hanger is supported and the position of the central string loop is \(x\)
Measure and record \(x\)
Add a \(10\mathrm{g}\) slotted mass to each mass hanger
Adjust the position of the rule until it is balanced
The distance between the centre of the hole from which the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass hanger is supported and the position of the central string loop is now \(y\) as shown in Fig. 2.3
Measure and record \(y\)
Calculate \((y - x)\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \((y - x)\)
percentage uncertainty = .........
Calculate \(m(A - 2y)\) where \(m = 10.0\mathrm{g}\)
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(m(A - 2y)\)
Add another \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass to each of the mass hangers and repeat **(c)(ii)**, **(c)(iii)** and **(c)(iv)**
y =
Calculate \(m(A - 2y)\) where \(m = 20.0\mathrm{g}\)
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)
first value of \(k =\)
second value of \(k =\)
Explain whether your results in (f)(i) support the suggested relationship
It is suggested that the relationship between \(y, x, m\) and \(A\) is
where \(k\) is a constant
Using your second value of \(k\), calculate the mass \(M\) of the metre rule using the relationship
where \(B = 150 \text{g}\)
Describe four sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
Describe four improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
[Total: 20]
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**
In this experiment, you will investigate the equilibrium of a balanced metre rule and determine its mass
